transcript:
Ten years ago,
sitting in my bedroom, when I was supposed to be studying
for a history test-- decided to whip out a phone, and record videos
to go public deep in the future and try to predict
what my life would be like, what the channel would be like… And after 10 incredibly long years, 'Hi Me In 10 Years'
finally went public. And I wanted to capture my reaction on this video
that you're watching now. So, let's do it. Hi, me in 10 years! Hey! Oh my God. I'm gonna schedule upload this video
10 years in the future. So, you're gonna see this in 2025. - Oh my God.
- It's 2015 for me right now. Ah, this is crazy!
Look how young I look! Look at the difference! This me doesn't have a beard,
doesn't have a mustache. Dude, what if I'm dead?
Dude, if I’m-- Oooh. That’d would be weird.
That'd be so weird. Thankfully, not dead. Oh, dude that’d be really weird. But, let's see. Ten-- Dude, if I don't have a million
subscribers when you see this video, my entire life has been a failure. Ironically, we actually have
dozens of channels with millions of subscribers. And before we go too deep into listening to old Jimmy,
17-year-old Jimmy here ramble, I just wanna like get you
in the right mindspace. I want you to understand what's going
through this 17-year-old's mind. We didn't have tons
of money growing up. I mean, it was probably like
a normal middle-class family. But in 2008,
we ended up going bankrupt. So we had nothing. Like, my parents actually filed
for bankruptcy… And I had poured year after year
after year of my life, and people weren’t
watching the videos… Everyone in my school,
everyone around me was saying, "Jimmy, you will never be a YouTuber.
This isn't realistic. You're chasing a fairytale and
you need to like actually focus on whatever you're actually
gonna do with your life…" And it started to really weigh on the
Jimmy you see here because he's like, "Am I wasting my life? Am I gonna be a failure?
Am I gonna be homeless? Will this ever work out?" And you know,
my mom didn't have much money, and I really wanted
to not be a burden on her. And I wanted to be able to make money
so I could help her… And all these thoughts are swirling and that like storm is what's
currently going on in this Jimmy you see here
10 years ago's mind. Now with that context,
let's keep watching. [sighs] Well by the time you see this,
I'll have finished high school. I did finish high school. Gone to college… Technically, I went to college. I went for 2 weeks, and then I thought
it was super boring and didn't go. It was a community college.
We could not afford real college. Probably be doing YouTube as a job.
Hopefully, maybe, maybe, maybe… I feel like back then, I'm like, "Man I would love to just be able
to provide for myself as a job!" And now I provide
for hundreds of families. I have hundreds
of full time employees, and we help thousands
upon thousands of people through our main channel videos, so… It is kind of funny in retrospect
that 10 years ago, which really isn't that far ago, I was nervous that I wouldn't be able
to provide for myself. Yeah, as of right now,
I'm enjoying YouTube. Hopefully I still--
future me still enjoys it. I don't think I'll ever get tired
of YouTube. Honestly, I think YouTube literally
runs in my veins at this point. I love creating content.
I love telling stories. I love entertaining people.
I love making your guys' day. I love being able to impact lives.
It's literally everything I love. I don't know, I--
it'd be crazy if I had some ridiculous
amount of subscribers. I bet you if you went back in time
and told this 17 year old me I'd have 440 million subscribers,
he wouldn't believe you. He would would laugh, right? Because back then, I think
the biggest channels in the world had like 10 million subscribers,
if that. Like, I remember when Smosh hit
10 million subscribers, and like being so mind blown, like,
whoa, that's huge, right? I remember when PewDiePie hit
10 million subscribers, I remember all those things. And like that seemed like
the pinnacle. It was like,
"Alright, they hit 10 million. They won the game!
Like, that's as big as it gets!" And like, now, I don't know. There's probably like a thousand
creators with 10 million subscribers. Like, it's just crazy
how much the platform has changed in the last decade. At the time I'm recording this video, I have 8,000 subscribers
and 1.8 million views. [Jimmy now] Wow. Look at that. Also, look at the old channel logo.
I kinda miss that tiger! The only problem, is it kinda looks
like a high school mascot. Just to be blunt,
this is why I ended up changing it. And the entire channel back then
had 1,830,631 views. Which is funny because
the main channel video does that in like 6 minutes
when we upload them. And it probably goes without saying, but I wanna make it
exceptionally clear, I am living a fairytale life
right now, and I just wanna make sure
everyone knows I'm very grateful. That 17-year-old,
if he could talk to you right now, to those of you
who watched the videos and allowed me
to become who I am today… he would be on his knees crying
and be eternally grateful. And obviously,
that 17-year-old is me now! And you know,
I'm not the best at being vulnerable and expressing emotion,
it’s not one of my strong suits… But, I want to make it
exceptionally clear that I'm beyond grateful
for all of you. I will never take this
for granted, and this is why I do everything
in my power to make every YouTube video we upload
on the MrBeast channel as freaking great
as freakin’ possible! So whenever you see this,
compare these numbers to whatever I have
when you watch this. Dude, I really hope
I have a million subs by now. - You have way more than a million!
- Please! Future me, please. - What am I doing with my hand?
- What am I doing with my hand… Please have a million subs! I probably should've thought about
what I was gonna say… hopefully you have a million subs. In case you're wondering,
I'm also talking a little quiet. It's actually 'cause
my mom's downstairs, and if she knew I was filming videos
as opposed to studying, she would come up there
and freak out. I'm pretty sure, actually,
one of these cuts is because my mom came in to check in
on me studying, and I had to, like, stop recording
and act like I was studying. Alright, so I should be studying
for a history test. [Jimmy now] Yup, the history test… I wonder if you, or me in 10 years,
remembers what grade I'm gonna get on this history test
that I take tomorrow, that I'm not studying for
because I'm making these videos. Dude, if you still remember
the grade I get on this history test in 10 years, that's crazy. I do remember the grade
I got on this test because after 'Hi Me in 1 Year,'
I went back and I looked at it and then I left a comment. Dude, I'm probably gonna be married
and stuff. Man… Well, you're not married,
but you're engaged. You will be married soon. You have a very beautiful fiancee,
Thea. Isn't she adorable? So, you're much closer
on that prediction than the sub count prediction! Woah, watch me not be married
and not have a million subscribers, not have any of this, and then you guys just think
I'm a big loser. I have most of those things, and a lot of you probably still think
I'm a loser. Dude, what if I don't do YouTube
when this goes public? That'd be weird. People don't realize this because I spend so many tens
of millions of dollars on videos now, but when I was starting out,
like I couldn't afford anything. I mean, look at the quality of this. Because I couldn't afford a camera. And so it's just so crazy that this somehow turned into
this life I'm living now. If you wanna see what time it is,
just so you know what the date is, that's the date. Oh, yeah. The squiggly lines is the date.
Thank you. Hopefully you can see that. [Jimmy now] We can't. Hopefully you still do YouTube. - Hey. Oh, my hair is messed up.
- Oh my gosh, this is so awesome. Alright yeah, I don't care. Hey, future me.
Hopefully you’re having a good day. [Jimmy now] I'm having
an awesome day. I better have a million
when this goes public. [Jimmy now]
You have more than a million. Chill. You hit your goal.
You're good. Ten years, man.
Ten years. - Yeah.
- I'm gonna be so different. - I really am gonna be so different.
- You are. You're different,
but not that different. I mean, back then,
I loved strategy games. I loved board games.
Obviously, I loved YouTube. A lot of my differences between 17-year-old me that you see here
and me now, is probably more in confidence. I was very self-conscious back then. Fun fact, I loved YouTube so much
when I was growing up that it was kinda all
I talked about. And one time, a high schooler came up
to me, and he's like, “All you do is talk about YouTube.
No one cares.” And that like really, really,
really hurt me because it kind of hit me. I was like, "Wow.
All I do is talk about YouTube." I talk about YouTubers
that are doing well. I talk about ideas. It was just like the thing
that consumed me when I was young. And so when I was around this age, I really, really struggled
because I was like, "Okay, no one cares about YouTube,
I just won't talk about it." And so I stopped talking
about YouTube, and it got to the point
where one time, one of my teachers asked, like,
"Am I mute?" Because like,
I talked so little. And I struggled really, really badly
to connect with people because all I wanted to talk about,
all I wanted to do, was improve videos,
and study videos, and work on videos
and entertain people. And if you're surrounded by people
who don't care at all by that stuff, that you just become
a nuisance to them. And so when you're that age, you have to be around the people
in your school, and there are people you just kinda
have to be around. And I was just forced
to be around people who truthfully made me feel
like a freak, and made me feel like
I didn't belong. And I didn't realize it ‘cause
I was so young that you know,
I'm not a freak. Or, maybe a little bit. But it's okay to be obsessed
with something. It's okay to love something. And so as soon as I got out of school
and I started hanging out with other people
who loved telling stories, who loved making content,
who loved being YouTubers, that's where everything changed. People who don't care
about content creation don't get it. And they think you're different
and weird and will call you names. But who cares? You don't need to be
around those people. And that's how I'll be happy, not by trying to change who I am,
if that makes sense. Oh, man. Man. Alright, well. [sighs] Actually, you know what
I just noticed? This gallon of water. For whatever reason,
I suck at drinking water. So I used to carry a gallon
of water around and try to like drink a gallon
of water throughout the day. A lot of you
probably don't know this, I have something called
Crohn's disease. It's where your gut kind of
attacks itself. It makes you very tired. Sometimes people will notice, like,
that I look low energy in videos. Or sometimes even people will say
I look soulless. Usually those images, those moments correlate when
my Crohn's is acting up. And I say all that because I played sports like crazy
growing up. But then when I was 15,
I got Crohn's disease. I ended up losing 60 pounds. I really struggled to get out
of bed. And this is like kinda
that weird time where I was like, "Oh well, now I suck at sports
'cause I have Crohn's," But I still like trained
quite a bit. And so that gallon you see
behind my head, I would drink a gallon of water
every day. So some days, I'd have like two baseball practices
in the same day. But I'd come home
and I'd grind YouTube videos, and then my mom would be like, “Do homework
and stop failing everything.” And I'd be like, “With what time?
I'm trying to be a YouTuber.” Alright, see you guys.
See you guys? - See me. Hey, me.
- [Jimmy now] Me, hey. One last thing, just so you know-- Look at that date.
8:27, October 4th, 2015. That's so crazy. It feels like
literally just yesterday, but it also feels like
10,000 years ago. That is crazy to look at. That little table you see
on the right, that was like a crappy little table
that I bought. This monitor is like a cheap little
monitor I bought at Best Buy. This is bringing back
so many memories, man. - It's currently October 4th.
- [Jimmy now] So many memories! So, yeah. Like I said,
this is October fou-. Oh, an abrupt ending. Lovely. I didn't learn how
to conclude a video, apparently. But anyways, my goodness. You know, to be honest,
I've been a big YouTuber for so long that sometimes I forget
about this past life. I forget about when I was 11, 12,
13 years old, 14 years old, 15 years old,
16 years old, these-- Year after year,
where I was making so many videos and pouring so many thousands
of hours into the channel and no one was watching them,
and I couldn't afford anything, and… It was a struggle, man.
It was a freaking struggle. I'm so just glad that
that young me there never gave up. I'm one of the most stubborn people
on the planet. Even now to this day,
if no one was watching the videos, I would still be making them. I decided that I was gonna be
a YouTuber, or I was gonna die. Those were the only
two outcomes in my life, is I'm gonna be a YouTuber,
or I'm gonna die. That's it. I worked very, very hard to build the channel
where it is today. But having said that,
there's obviously luck involved. And I would say the luckiest thing
that ever happened to me, is I, at a very young age,
found what I loved. That 100% is the luckiest thing
that ever happened to me in my life. Which is why
I wanna encourage you guys. You know, obviously,
not everyone's in a position where they can just
chase their dreams, and… You know, you have to put food
on the table if you have kids, and you have to provide
for yourself. But if you do have time
outside of your job and what you're doing
to provide, really try to find
what you love. Because when you do find
what you love, and it finally works out,
it's amazing. I'm so grateful for the life I live. I'm so grateful for the life you guys
allow me to live. I love everything I do. I love it, I love it,
I love it so much. And so thank you, thank you…
Thank you guys. I hope you enjoyed, and let me know
if I should react to other stuff.
